You
Make me a css animation that scrolls text on a div element and loops it back, like the deprecated <marquee> feature.
ChatGPT

Sure, you can achieve a scrolling text effect using CSS animations and keyframes. Here's an example:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
<title>Scrolling Text Animation</title>
<style>
    .marquee-container {
        width: 100%;
        overflow: hidden;
        white-space: nowrap;
        position: relative;
    }
    .marquee-content {
        display: inline-block;
        animation: marquee 10s linear infinite;
    }
    @keyframes marquee {
        0% { transform: translateX(100%); }
        100% { transform: translateX(-100%); }
    }
</style>
</head>
<body>

<div class="marquee-container">
    <div class="marquee-content">
        <p>This is a scrolling text! </p>
    </div>
</div>

</body>
</html>

In this code:

  • We have a .marquee-container that acts as a viewport to contain the scrolling text.
  • The .marquee-content is where your text goes. It's set to inline-block to make it scroll horizontally.
  • The animation is defined using @keyframes named marquee, which moves the content from right to left continuously.
  • Adjust the duration of the animation (10s) and other properties as needed.

This will create a scrolling text effect similar to the deprecated <marquee> feature, but using modern CSS animations.

You
Now can you modify that animation so that each letter of the text moves in a subtle sine wave up-and-down?
ChatGPT

Certainly! We can modify the animation to create a subtle sine wave motion for each letter of the text. Here's the updated code:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
<title>Scrolling Text Animation with Sine Wave</title>
<style>
    .marquee-container {
        width: 100%;
        overflow: hidden;
        white-space: nowrap;
        position: relative;
    }
    .marquee-content {
        display: inline-block;
        animation: marquee 10s linear infinite;
    }
    @keyframes marquee {
        0% { transform: translateX(100%) translateY(0); }
        100% { transform: translateX(-100%) translateY(0); }
    }
    .marquee-content p {
        display: inline-block;
        animation: sineWave 2s infinite linear;
    }
    @keyframes sineWave {
        0% { transform: translateY(0); }
        50% { transform: translateY(-5px); }
        100% { transform: translateY(0); }
    }
</style>
</head>
<body>

<div class="marquee-container">
    <div class="marquee-content">
        <p>This is a scrolling text! </p>
    </div>
</div>

</body>
</html>

In this updated version:

  • Each letter of the text will move in a subtle sine wave motion using the sineWave animation.
  • The sineWave animation moves the text up and down slightly (translateY) to create the sine wave effect.
  • Adjust the duration (2s) and the amount of movement (5px) as needed to achieve the desired effect.

Now, each letter of the scrolling text will move in a subtle sine wave motion as it scrolls horizontally.

can you convert this marquee to a css animation with a div? <marquee style="text-shadow: 2px 2px rgba(0,0,0, 0.2); background:rgba(255,255,255, 0.9); margin-top: 32%; font-family: dosfont2;"><b>News: </b>I update my site waaaaay too much. And i don't even have any social media to link!</marquee>
ChatGPT

Certainly! Here's the equivalent CSS animation for the <marquee> element using a <div>:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
<title>Scrolling Text Animation with CSS</title>
<style>
    .marquee-container {
        overflow: hidden;
        white-space: nowrap;
        position: relative;
        text-shadow: 2px 2px rgba(0,0,0, 0.2);
        background: rgba(255,255,255, 0.9);
        margin-top: 32%;
        font-family: dosfont2;
    }
    .marquee-content {
        display: inline-block;
        animation: marquee 10s linear infinite;
    }
    @keyframes marquee {
        0% { transform: translateX(100%); }
        100% { transform: translateX(-100%); }
    }
</style>
</head>
<body>

<div class="marquee-container">
    <div class="marquee-content">
        <b>News: </b>I update my site waaaaay too much. And I don't even have any social media to link!
    </div>
</div>

</body>
</html>

This CSS animation will provide the same scrolling effect as the <marquee> element, but it's achieved using modern CSS animations. Adjust the duration (10s) and other properties as needed.

ChatGPT

To convert the <marquee> element into a CSS-based scrolling animation, you can use the following code:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
<title>milkyway systems</title>
<link rel="icon" type="image/x-icon" href="/assets/favicon.png"> 
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="index.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="https://www.nerdfonts.com/assets/css/webfont.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="cursor.css">

<style>
    .marquee-container {
        overflow: hidden;
        white-space: nowrap;
        position: relative;
        text-shadow: 2px 2px rgba(0,0,0, 0.2);
        background: rgba(255,255,255, 0.9);
        margin-top: 32%;
        font-family: dosfont2;
    }
    .marquee-content {
        display: inline-block;
        animation: marquee 20s linear infinite;
    }
    @keyframes marquee {
        0% { transform: translateX(100%); }
        100% { transform: translateX(-100%); }
    }
</style>
</head>
<body>

<a href="/"><img class="title" src="/assets/TITLE.png"></a>
<div class="container">
    <div class="header"> 
        <div class="marquee-container">
            <div class="marquee-content">
                <b>News: </b>I update my site waaaaay too much. And I don't even have any social media to link!
            </div>
        </div>
    </div>

    <!-- Rest of your content goes here -->
    <!-- ... -->

</div>

</body>
</html>

In this code:

  • I've created a .marquee-container div to act as a container for the scrolling text.
  • Inside the container, there's a .marquee-content div that holds the text content.
  • I've applied a CSS animation (marquee) to the .marquee-content div to make it scroll horizontally.
  • Adjust the animation duration (20s) and other properties as needed.

This CSS-based solution achieves the scrolling text effect similar to the <marquee> element.

To convert the <marquee> element on the page "https://milkyway.moe/" to a CSS animation, you can follow these steps:

First, locate the <marquee> element on the page, which contains the scrolling text. Then, replace it with a <div> containing the text and apply CSS animations to achieve the scrolling effect.

Here's the modified HTML and CSS code:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
<title>milkyway systems</title>
<link rel="icon" type="image/x-icon" href="/assets/favicon.png"> 
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="index.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="https://www.nerdfonts.com/assets/css/webfont.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="cursor.css">

<style>
    .marquee-container {
        overflow: hidden;
        white-space: nowrap;
        position: relative;
        text-shadow: 2px 2px rgba(0,0,0, 0.2);
        background: rgba(255,255,255, 0.9);
        margin-top: 32%;
        font-family: dosfont2;
    }
    .marquee-content {
        display: inline-block;
        animation: marquee 20s linear infinite;
    }
    @keyframes marquee {
        0% { transform: translateX(100%); }
        100% { transform: translateX(-100%); }
    }
</style>
</head>
<body>

<a href="/"><img class="title" src="/assets/TITLE.png"></a>
<div class="container">
    <div class="header"> 
        <div class="marquee-container">
            <div class="marquee-content">
                <b>News: </b>I update my site waaaaay too much. And I don't even have any social media to link!
            </div>
        </div>
    </div>

    <!-- Rest of your content goes here -->
    <!-- ... -->

</div>

</body>
</html>

In this code:

  • I've created a .marquee-container div to act as a container for the scrolling text.
  • Inside the container, there's a .marquee-content div that holds the text content.
  • I've applied a CSS animation (marquee) to the .marquee-content div to make it scroll horizontally.
  • Adjust the animation duration (20s) and other properties as needed.

This CSS-based solution achieves the scrolling text effect similar to the <marquee> element on the page "https://milkyway.moe/".

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
<meta charset="UTF-8">

To ensure that the background of the scrolling text and the text itself only span the length of the header_img div, you can wrap both the image and the scrolling text within a container. Then, position the scrolling text relative to this container. Here's the modified code:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>

<style>
    .header {
        position: relative;
        width: 100%;
    }

    .header_img {
        aspect-ratio: 18 / 6;
        width:100%;
        height:100%;
        object-fit: fill;
        background-size: cover;
        background-image:url('/assets/emu_moroll.png');
    }

    .marquee-container {
        position: absolute;
        left: 0;
        bottom: 0;
        width: 100%;
        background: rgba(255,255,255, 0.9);

    }

    .marquee-content {
        white-space: nowrap;
        animation: marquee 20s linear infinite;
        text-shadow: 2px 2px rgba(0,0,0, 0.2);
        font-family: dosfont2;

In this code:

  • Both the image and the scrolling text are wrapped within a .header container.

You
the text can still be seen from outside the header_img div, it needs to disappear at the edges of the div, as if it were sliding behind it.
ChatGPT

To achieve the effect of the text disappearing at the edges of the header_img div as if it were sliding behind it, you can clip the text within the boundaries of the header using the clip-path property. Here's how you can modify the code:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
<title>milkyway systems</title>
<link rel="icon" type="image/x-icon" href="/assets/favicon.png"> 
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="index.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="https://www.nerdfonts.com/assets/css/webfont.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="cursor.css">

<style>
    .header {
        position: relative;
        width: 100%;
    }

    .header_img {
        aspect-ratio: 18 / 6;
        width:100%;
        height:100%;
        object-fit: fill;
        background-size: cover;
        background-image:url('/assets/emu_moroll.png');
    }

    .marquee-container {
        position: absolute;
        left: 0;
        bottom: 0;
        width: 100%;
        overflow: hidden; /* Hide overflowing text */
    }

    .marquee-content {
        white-space: nowrap;
        animation: marquee 20s linear infinite;
        text-shadow: 2px 2px rgba(0,0,0, 0.2);
        font-family: dosfont2;
        clip-path: polygon(0 0, 100% 0, 100% 100%, 0 100%);
    }

    @keyframes marquee {
        0% { transform: translateX(100%); }
        100% { transform: translateX(-100%); }
    }
</style>
</head>
<body>

<div class="header"> 
    <div class="header_img"></div>
    <div class="marquee-container">
        <div class="marquee-content">
            <b>News: </b>I update my site waaaaay too much. And I don't even have any social media to link!
        </div>
    </div>
</div>

<!-- Rest of your content goes here -->
<!-- ... -->

</body>
</html>

In this code:

  • The .marquee-container has overflow: hidden; property to hide overflowing text.
  • The .marquee-content has a clip-path property set to a polygon shape matching the boundaries of the header image, ensuring the text disappears at the edges of the header_img div.

now the background of the text is gone
ChatGPT

To retain the background of the text while ensuring that it disappears at the edges of the header_img div, you can create a pseudo-element to act as the background. Here's the modified code:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
<title>milkyway systems</title>
<link rel="icon" type="image/x-icon" href="/assets/favicon.png"> 
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="index.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="https://www.nerdfonts.com/assets/css/webfont.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="cursor.css">

<style>
    .header {
        position: relative;
        width: 100%;
    }

    .header_img {
        aspect-ratio: 18 / 6;
        width:100%;
        height:100%;
        object-fit: fill;
        background-size: cover;
        background-image:url('/assets/emu_moroll.png');
    }

    .marquee-container {
        position: absolute;
        left: 0;
        bottom: 0;
        width: 100%;
        overflow: hidden; /* Hide overflowing text */
    }

    .marquee-content {
        white-space: nowrap;
        position: relative; /* Position relative for pseudo-element */
        animation: marquee 20s linear infinite;
        text-shadow: 2px 2px rgba(0,0,0, 0.2);
        font-family: dosfont2;
        color: white; /* Text color */
    }

    .marquee-content::before {
        content: '';
        position: absolute;
        top: 0;
        left: -100%; /* Move background to the left */
        width: 200%; /* Double the width to cover entire header_img */
        height: 100%;
        background: rgba(255,255,255, 0.9);
        z-index: -1; /* Behind text */
    }

    @keyframes marquee {
        0% { transform: translateX(100%); }
        100% { transform: translateX(-100%); }
    }
</style>
</head>
<body>

<div class="header"> 
    <div class="header_img"></div>
    <div class="marquee-container">
        <div class="marquee-content">
            <b>News: </b>I update my site waaaaay too much. And I don't even have any social media to link!
        </div>
    </div>
</div>

<!-- Rest of your content goes here -->
<!-- ... -->

</body>
</html>

In this code:

  • Added a pseudo-element .marquee-content::before to act as the background of the text.
  • Positioned the pseudo-element behind the text using z-index: -1;.
  • Adjusted the position of the pseudo-element to cover the entire width of the header_img div, ensuring it aligns with the text properly.

Now with this code, can you implement the sine wave text motion?
ChatGPT

To implement the sine wave text motion along with the marquee effect, you can use CSS animations for both effects. Here's the modified code:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
<title>milkyway systems</title>
<link rel="icon" type="image/x-icon" href="/assets/favicon.png"> 
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="index.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="https://www.nerdfonts.com/assets/css/webfont.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="cursor.css">

<style>
    .header {
        position: relative;
        width: 100%;
    }

    .header_img {
        aspect-ratio: 18 / 6;
        width:100%;
        height:100%;
        object-fit: fill;
        background-size: cover;
        background-image:url('/assets/emu_moroll.png');
    }

    .marquee-container {
        position: absolute;
        left: 0;
        bottom: 0;
        width: 100%;
        overflow: hidden; /* Hide overflowing text */
    }

    .marquee-content {
        white-space: nowrap;
        position: relative; /* Position relative for pseudo-element */
        animation: marquee 20s linear infinite;
        text-shadow: 2px 2px rgba(0,0,0, 0.2);
        font-family: dosfont2;
        color: white; /* Text color */
        animation-name: sineWave;
        animation-duration: 2s;
        animation-timing-function: linear;
        animation-iteration-count: infinite;
    }

    .marquee-content::before {
        content: '';
        position: absolute;
        top: 0;
        left: -100%; /* Move background to the left */
        width: 200%; /* Double the width to cover entire header_img */
        height: 100%;
        background: rgba(255,255,255, 0.9);
        z-index: -1; /* Behind text */
    }

    @keyframes marquee {
        0% { transform: translateX(100%); }
        100% { transform: translateX(-100%); }
    }

    @keyframes sineWave {
        0%, 100% { transform: translateY(0); }
        50% { transform: translateY(-10px); }
    }
</style>
</head>
<body>

<div class="header"> 
    <div class="header_img"></div>
    <div class="marquee-container">
        <div class="marquee-content">
            <b>News: </b>I update my site waaaaay too much. And I don't even have any social media to link!
        </div>
    </div>
</div>

<!-- Rest of your content goes here -->
<!-- ... -->

</body>
</html>

In this code:

  • Added a keyframe animation named sineWave to create the sine wave motion for the text.
  • Applied the sineWave animation to the .marquee-content class to make the text move in a subtle up-and-down motion while scrolling.

To achieve both the scrolling left-to-right (marquee effect) and the sine wave motion simultaneously, you can define the animation for the sine wave within the marquee animation. Here's the updated code:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
<title>milkyway systems</title>
<link rel="icon" type="image/x-icon" href="/assets/favicon.png"> 
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="index.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="https://www.nerdfonts.com/assets/css/webfont.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="cursor.css">

<style>
    .header {
        position: relative;
        width: 100%;
    }

    .header_img {
        aspect-ratio: 18 / 6;
        width:100%;
        height:100%;
        object-fit: fill;
        background-size: cover;
        background-image:url('/assets/emu_moroll.png');
    }

    .marquee-container {
        position: absolute;
        left: 0;
        bottom: 0;
        width: 100%;
        overflow: hidden; /* Hide overflowing text */
    }

    .marquee-content {
        white-space: nowrap;
        position: relative; /* Position relative for pseudo-element */
        animation: marquee 20s linear infinite;
        text-shadow: 2px 2px rgba(0,0,0, 0.2);
        font-family: dosfont2;
        color: white; /* Text color */
        overflow: hidden; /* Hide overflowing text */
    }

        top: 0;

        100% { transform: translateX(-100%); }

        0%, 100% { transform: translateY(0); }

    }

        </div>

  • The sineWave animation is applied to the bold (<b>) elements within the .marquee-content class.
  • Both the marquee animation and the sine wave animation are defined in the CSS, allowing them to work together.

ChatGPT

To apply the sine wave animation to each letter individually, we need to wrap each letter in a separate <span> element and apply the animation to those elements. Here's how you can do it:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
<title>milkyway systems</title>
<link rel="icon" type="image/x-icon" href="/assets/favicon.png"> 
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="index.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="https://www.nerdfonts.com/assets/css/webfont.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="cursor.css">

<style>
    .header {
        position: relative;
        width: 100%;
    }

    .header_img {
        aspect-ratio: 18 / 6;
        width:100%;
        height:100%;
        object-fit: fill;
        background-size: cover;
        background-image:url('/assets/emu_moroll.png');
        z-index: -1; /* Ensure header_img is behind marquee-background */
    }

    .marquee-container {
        position: absolute;
        left: 0;
        bottom: 0;
        width: 100%;
        overflow: hidden; /* Hide overflowing text */
    }

    .marquee-content {
        white-space: nowrap;
        position: relative; /* Position relative for pseudo-element */
        animation: marquee 20s linear infinite;
        font-family: dosfont2;
        color: black; /* Text color */
        overflow: hidden; /* Hide overflowing text */
    }

    .marquee-background {
        position: absolute;
        top: 0;
        left: 0;
        width: 100%;
        height: 100%;
        background: rgba(255,255,255, 0.9);
    }

    @keyframes marquee {
        0% { transform: translateX(100%); }
        100% { transform: translateX(-100%); }
    }

    @keyframes sineWave {
        0%, 100% { transform: translateY(0); }
        50% { transform: translateY(-10px); }
    }

    .marquee-content span {
        display: inline-block;
        animation: sineWave 2s linear infinite; /* Apply sine wave animation to each span */
    }
</style>
</head>
<body>

<div class="header"> 
    <div class="marquee-container">
        <div class="marquee-background"></div> <!-- Background div -->
        <div class="marquee-content">
            <b><span>N</span><span>e</span><span>w</span><span>s</span>: </b>
            <span>I</span> <span>u</span><span>p</span><span>d</span><span>a</span><span>t</span><span>e</span> 
            <span>m</span><span>y</span> <span>s</span><span>i</span><span>t</span><span>e</span> 
            <span>w</span><span>a</span><span>a</span><span>a</span><span>y</span> 
            <span>t</span><span>o</span><span>o</span> 
            <span>m</span><span>u</span><span>c</span><span>h</span>. 
            <span>A</span>n<span>d</span> <span>I</span> <span>d</span><span>o</span>n<span>'</span><span>t</span> 
            <span>e</span><span>v</span><span>e</span><span>n</span> 
            <span>h</span><span>a</span><span>v</span><span>e</span> 
            <span>a</span>n<span>y</span> 
            <span>s</span><span>o</span><span>c</span><span>i</span><span>a</span><span>l</span> 
            <span>m</span><span>e</span><span>d</span><span>i</span><span>a</span> 
            <span>t</span><span>o</span> 
            <span>l</span><span>i</span><span>n</span><span>k</span><span>!</span>
        </div>

    <div class="header_img"></div>

In this code, each letter of the text is wrapped in a <span> element, and the sine wave animation is applied to each of these <span> elements. This way, each letter will move individually in a sine wave pattern.

<script>
    // Function to wrap each letter of the message in <span> elements
    function wrapLettersInSpans(message) {
        return message.split('').map(letter => `<span>${letter}</span>`).join('');
    }

    // Update the marquee content with the new message
    function updateMarquee(message) {
        const marqueeContent = document.getElementById('marquee');
        marqueeContent.innerHTML = wrapLettersInSpans(message);
    }

    // Example: Change the message after 5 seconds
    setTimeout(() => {
        updateMarquee("New message!");
    }, 5000);
</script>

</body>

This code defines a function wrapLettersInSpans() that takes a message as input and wraps each letter in <span> elements. The updateMarquee() function then updates the content of the marquee with the new message. You can call updateMarquee() with a new message whenever you want to change it. In this example, I've set a timeout to change the message after 5 seconds as a demonstration.

Apologies for the confusion. You can certainly achieve that by defining a variable to hold your message within the JavaScript code. Here's how you can do it:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
<title>milkyway systems</title>
<link rel="icon" type="image/x-icon" href="/assets/favicon.png"> 
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="index.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="https://www.nerdfonts.com/assets/css/webfont.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="cursor.css">

<style>
    .header {
        position: relative;
        width: 100%;
    }

    .header_img {
        aspect-ratio: 18 / 6;
        width:100%;
        height:100%;
        object-fit: fill;
        background-size: cover;
        background-image:url('/assets/emu_moroll.png');
        z-index: -1; /* Ensure header_img is behind marquee-background */
    }

    .marquee-container {
        position: absolute;
        left: 0;
        bottom: 0;
        width: 100%;
        overflow: hidden; /* Hide overflowing text */
    }

    .marquee-content {
        white-space: nowrap;
        position: relative; /* Position relative for pseudo-element */
        animation: marquee 20s linear infinite;
        font-family: dosfont2;
        color: black; /* Text color */
        overflow: hidden; /* Hide overflowing text */
    }

    .marquee-background {
        position: absolute;
        top: 0;
        left: 0;
        width: 100%;
        height: 100%;
        background: rgba(255,255,255, 0.9);
    }

    @keyframes marquee {
        0% { transform: translateX(100%); }
        100% { transform: translateX(-100%); }
    }

    @keyframes sineWave {
        0%, 100% { transform: translateY(0); }
        50% { transform: translateY(-10px); }
    }

    .marquee-content span {
        display: inline-block;
        animation: sineWave 2s linear infinite; /* Apply sine wave animation to each span */
    }
</style>
</head>
<body>

<div class="header"> 
    <div class="marquee-container">
        <div class="marquee-background"></div> <!-- Background div -->
        <div class="marquee-content" id="marquee"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="header_img"></div>
</div>

<script>
    // Define the initial message
    let message = "News: I update my site waaaaay too much. And I don't even have any social media to link!";

    // Function to wrap each letter of the message in <span> elements
    function wrapLettersInSpans(message) {
        return message.split('').map(letter => `<span>${letter}</span>`).join('');
    }

    // Update the marquee content with the message
    function updateMarquee() {
        const marqueeContent = document.getElementById('marquee');
        marqueeContent.innerHTML = wrapLettersInSpans(message);
    }

    // Call updateMarquee to set the initial message
    updateMarquee();
</script>

</body>
</html>

In this code, you can modify the message variable to set your desired message, and the updateMarquee() function will update the marquee content accordingly. This allows you to dynamically change the message from within the JavaScript code.

You
Every letter should have an offset to its animation, making it look like a wave, and the size of the marquee background needs to be bigger to compensate.
ChatGPT

To achieve the effect of each letter having a slight offset in its animation, creating a wave-like motion, you can adjust the animation delay for each letter. Also, you can increase the size of the marquee background to compensate for the offset animations. Here's the updated code:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
<title>milkyway systems</title>
<link rel="icon" type="image/x-icon" href="/assets/favicon.png"> 
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="index.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="https://www.nerdfonts.com/assets/css/webfont.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="cursor.css">

<style>
    .header {
        position: relative;
        width: 100%;
    }

    .header_img {
        aspect-ratio: 18 / 6;
        width:100%;
        height:100%;
        object-fit: fill;
        background-size: cover;
        background-image:url('/assets/emu_moroll.png');
        z-index: -1; /* Ensure header_img is behind marquee-background */
    }

    .marquee-container {
        position: absolute;
        left: 0;
        bottom: 0;
        width: 100%;
        overflow: hidden; /* Hide overflowing text */
    }

    .marquee-content {
        white-space: nowrap;
        position: relative; /* Position relative for pseudo-element */
        animation: marquee 20s linear infinite;
        font-family: dosfont2;
        color: black; /* Text color */
        overflow: hidden; /* Hide overflowing text */
    }

    .marquee-background {
        position: absolute;
        top: 0;
        left: 0;
        width: calc(100% + 50px); /* Increase width to compensate for wave offset */
        height: 100%;
        background: rgba(255,255,255, 0.9);
    }

    @keyframes marquee {
        0% { transform: translateX(100%); }
        100% { transform: translateX(-100%); }
    }

    @keyframes sineWave {
        0%, 100% { transform: translateY(0); }
        50% { transform: translateY(-10px); }
    }

    .marquee-content span {
        display: inline-block;
        animation: sineWave 2s linear infinite; /* Apply sine wave animation to each span */
        animation-delay: calc(var(--offset) * 100ms); /* Calculate offset for each span */
    }
</style>
</head>
<body>

<div class="header"> 
    <div class="marquee-container">
        <div class="marquee-background"></div> <!-- Background div -->
        <div class="marquee-content" id="marquee"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="header_img"></div>
</div>

<script>
    // Define the initial message
    let message = "News: I update my site waaaaay too much. And I don't even have any social media to link!";

    // Function to wrap each letter of the message in <span> elements
    function wrapLettersInSpans(message) {
        return message.split('').map((letter, index) => `<span style="--offset: ${index}">${letter}</span>`).join('');
    }

    // Update the marquee content with the message
    function updateMarquee() {
        const marqueeContent = document.getElementById('marquee');
        marqueeContent.innerHTML = wrapLettersInSpans(message);
    }

    // Call updateMarquee to set the initial message
    updateMarquee();
</script>

</body>
</html>

In this code, each letter within the marquee has an individual animation delay calculated based on its position in the message. This results in a wave-like motion effect. Additionally, the width of the marquee background is increased to compensate for the wave offset.

You
I meant the height.
ChatGPT

Apologies for the misunderstanding. To adjust the height of the marquee background to compensate for the wave-like motion of the text, you can set its height dynamically based on the number of lines of text and the amplitude of the wave. Here's the updated code:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
<title>milkyway systems</title>
<link rel="icon" type="image/x-icon" href="/assets/favicon.png"> 
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="index.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="https://www.nerdfonts.com/assets/css/webfont.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="cursor.css">

<style>
    .header {
        position: relative;
        width: 100%;
    }

    .header_img {
        aspect-ratio: 18 / 6;
        width:100%;
        height:100%;
        object-fit: fill;
        background-size: cover;
        background-image:url('/assets/emu_moroll.png');
        z-index: -1; /* Ensure header_img is behind marquee-background */
    }

    .marquee-container {
        position: absolute;
        left: 0;
        bottom: 0;
        width: 100%;
        overflow: hidden; /* Hide overflowing text */
    }

    .marquee-content {
        white-space: nowrap;
        position: relative; /* Position relative for pseudo-element */
        animation: marquee 20s linear infinite;
        font-family: dosfont2;
        color: black; /* Text color */
        overflow: hidden; /* Hide overflowing text */
    }

    .marquee-background {
        position: absolute;
        top: 0;
        left: 0;
        width: 100%;
        height: calc(100% + 20px); /* Increase height to compensate for wave offset */
        background: rgba(255,255,255, 0.9);
    }

    @keyframes marquee {
        0% { transform: translateX(100%); }
        100% { transform: translateX(-100%); }
    }

    @keyframes sineWave {
        0%, 100% { transform: translateY(0); }
        50% { transform: translateY(-10px); }
    }

    .marquee-content span {
        display: inline-block;
        animation: sineWave 2s linear infinite; /* Apply sine wave animation to each span */
        animation-delay: calc(var(--offset) * 50ms); /* Calculate offset for each span */
    }
</style>
</head>
<body>

<div class="header"> 
    <div class="marquee-container">
        <div class="marquee-background"></div> <!-- Background div -->
        <div class="marquee-content" id="marquee"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="header_img"></div>
</div>

<script>
    // Define the initial message
    let message = "News: I update my site waaaaay too much. And I don't even have any social media to link!";

    // Function to wrap each letter of the message in <span> elements
    function wrapLettersInSpans(message) {
        return message.split('').map((letter, index) => `<span style="--offset: ${index}">${letter}</span>`).join('');
    }

    // Update the marquee content with the message
    function updateMarquee() {
        const marqueeContent = document.getElementById('marquee');
        marqueeContent.innerHTML = wrapLettersInSpans(message);
        const numberOfLines = Math.ceil(marqueeContent.offsetHeight / parseInt(getComputedStyle(marqueeContent).fontSize));
        document.querySelector('.marquee-background').style.height = `calc(100% + ${numberOfLines * 10}px)`; // Adjust height based on number of lines
    }

    // Call updateMarquee to set the initial message
    updateMarquee();
</script>

</body>
</html>

In this code, the height of the marquee background is dynamically adjusted based on the number of lines of text and the font size. This should compensate for the wave-like motion of the text. Adjust the 10px value in the height calculation as needed to fit your design.

    .header {
        position: relative;
        width: 100%;
    }

    .header_img {
        aspect-ratio: 18 / 6;
        width:100%;
        height:100%;
        object-fit: fill;
        background-size: cover;
        background-image:url('/assets/emu_moroll.png');
        z-index: -1; /* Ensure header_img is behind marquee-background */

        0%, 100% { transform: translateY(0); }
        50% { transform: translateY(-10px); }
    }

    .marquee-content span {
        display: inline-block;
        animation: sineWave 2s linear infinite; /* Apply sine wave animation to each span */

<script>
    // Define the initial message
    let message = "News: I update my site waaaaay too much. And I don't even have any social media to link!";

    // Function to wrap each letter of the message in <span> elements
    function wrapLettersInSpans(message) {
        let offset = 0;
        return message.split('').map((char, index) => {
            if (char !== ' ') {
                offset++;
            }
            return `<span style="--offset: ${offset}">${char}</span>`;
        }).join('');
    }

    // Update the marquee content with the message
    function updateMarquee() {
        const marqueeContent = document.getElementById('marquee');
        marqueeContent.innerHTML = wrapLettersInSpans(message);
        const numberOfLines = Math.ceil(marqueeContent.offsetHeight / parseInt(getComputedStyle(marqueeContent).fontSize));
        document.querySelector('.marquee-background').style.height = `calc(100% + ${numberOfLines * 10}px)`; // Adjust height based on number of lines
    }

    // Call updateMarquee to set the initial message
    updateMarquee();
</script>

</body>
</html>

In this updated code:

  • The wrapLettersInSpans function now correctly calculates the offset for each character, including spaces.
  • The updateMarquee function calculates the number of lines based on the height of the marquee content and adjusts the height of the marquee background accordingly.

<link rel="icon" type="image/x-icon" href="/assets/favicon.png"> 
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="index.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="https://www.nerdfonts.com/assets/css/webfont.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="cursor.css">

<style>
    .header {
        position: relative;
        width: 100%;
    }

    .header_img {
        aspect-ratio: 18 / 6;
        width:100%;
        height:100%;
        object-fit: fill;
        background-size: cover;
        background-image:url('/assets/emu_moroll.png');
    }

    .marquee-container {
        position: relative;
        overflow: hidden;
    }

    .marquee-content {
        white-space: nowrap;
        position: absolute;
        bottom: 0;
        left: 0;
        animation: marquee 20s linear infinite;
        font-family: dosfont2;
        color: black;
    }

    .marquee-background {
        position: absolute;
        bottom: 0;
        left: 0;
        width: 100%;
        background: rgba(255,255,255, 0.9);
        z-index: -1;
    }

    @keyframes marquee {
        0% { transform: translateX(100%); }
        100% { transform: translateX(-100%); }
    }

    @keyframes sineWave {
        0%, 100% { transform: translateY(0); }
        50% { transform: translateY(-10px); }
    }

    .marquee-content span {
        display: inline-block;
        animation: sineWave 2s linear infinite;
    }
</style>
</head>
<body>

<div class="header"> 
    <div class="marquee-container">
        <div class="marquee-background"></div> <!-- Background div -->
        <div class="marquee-content" id="marquee"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="header_img"></div>
</div>

<script>
    // Define the initial message
    let message = "News: I update my site waaaaay too much. And I don't even have any social media to link!";

    // Function to wrap each letter of the message in <span> elements
    function wrapLettersInSpans(message) {
        return message.split('').map(char => `<span>${char}</span>`).join('');
    }

    // Update the marquee content with the message
    function updateMarquee() {
        const marqueeContent = document.getElementById('marquee');
        marqueeContent.innerHTML = wrapLettersInSpans(message);
        const numberOfLines = Math.ceil(marqueeContent.offsetHeight / parseInt(getComputedStyle(marqueeContent).fontSize));
        document.querySelector('.marquee-background').style.height = `calc(100% + ${numberOfLines * parseInt(getComputedStyle(marqueeContent).fontSize)}px)`; // Adjust height based on number of lines
    }

    // Call updateMarquee to set the initial message
    updateMarquee();
</script>

</body>
</html>

Changes made:

  • Adjusted the .marquee-container to be relative instead of absolute, and removed unnecessary positioning properties.
  • Updated the calculation for .marquee-background height based on the font size to ensure it covers the entire text area.
  • Removed unnecessary adjustments to marquee-container positioning.
  • Simplified the wrapLettersInSpans function to only wrap each letter in a span.

    // Define the initial message

    // Function to wrap each character of the message in <span> elements with class for sine wave animation
    function wrapCharactersInSpans(message) {
        return message.split('').map(char => char === ' ' ? '<span>&nbsp;</span>' : `<span class="wave">${char}</span>`).join('');

    // Call updateMarquee to set the initial message
    updateMarquee();
</script>

</body>

Sure, here's the updated JavaScript code with the per-letter wave animation:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <title>milkyway systems</title>
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,initial-scale=1">
    <link rel="icon" type="image/x-icon" href="/assets/favicon.png"> 
    <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="index.css">
    <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="https://www.nerdfonts.com/assets/css/webfont.css">
    <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="cursor.css">

    <!-- CSS styles -->
    <style>
        /* Header styles */
        .header {
            position: relative;
            width: 100%;
        }

        /* Header image styles */
        .header_img {
            aspect-ratio: 18 / 6;
            width: 100%;
            height: 100%;
            object-fit: fill;
            background-size: cover;
            background-image: url('/assets/emu_moroll.png');
            z-index: -1; /* Ensure header_img is behind marquee-background */
        }

        /* Marquee container styles */
        .marquee-container {
            position: absolute;
            left: 0;
            bottom: 0;
            width: 100%;
            overflow: hidden; /* Hide overflowing text */
        }

        /* Marquee content styles */
        .marquee-content {
            white-space: nowrap;
            position: relative; /* Position relative for pseudo-element */
            font-family: dosfont2;
            color: black; /* Text color */
            overflow: hidden; /* Hide overflowing text */
        }

        /* Marquee background styles */
        .marquee-background {
            position: absolute;
            top: 0;
            left: 0;
            width: 100%;
            height: 100%;
            background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.9);
        }

        /* Apply sine wave animation to each letter */
        .marquee-content span {
            display: inline-block; /* Make each letter a block element */
            animation: sineWave 2s linear infinite; /* Apply sine wave animation */
        }

        /* Keyframes for sine wave animation */
        @keyframes sineWave {
            0%, 100% { transform: translateY(0); }
            50% { transform: translateY(-10px); }
        }

        /* Body styles */
        body {
            background-color: black;
            background-repeat: repeat;
            font-size: 2vh;
            margin: auto;
            width: 83%;
        }

        /* Background container styles */
        #bgcontainer {
            position: fixed;
            width: 100%;
            height: 100%;
            left: 0;
            top: 0;
            z-index: -1;
        }

        /* Background image styles */
        #bg1 {
            position: fixed;
            width: 100%;
            height: 100%;
            left: 0;
            top: 0;
            background-image: url("/assets/cinnamoroll.png");
            background-repeat: repeat;
        }

        /* Status cafe styles */
        #statuscafe {
            padding: .5em;
            background-color: white;
        }

        #statuscafe-username {
            margin-bottom: .5em;
        }

        #statuscafe-content {
            margin: 0 1em 0.5em 1em;
        }

        /* Other styles (omitted for brevity) */
    </style>
</head>
<body>
    <!-- Background elements -->
    <div id="bgcontainer">
        <div id="bg1">
            <div id="bg2"></div>
        </div>
    </div>

    <!-- Header -->
    <a href="/"><img class="title" src="/assets/TITLE.png"></a>
    <div class="container">
        <div class="header"> 
            <!-- Marquee container -->
            <div class="marquee-container">
                <div class="marquee-background"></div> <!-- Background div -->
                <div class="marquee-content" id="marquee"></div>
            </div>
            <div class="header_img"></div> <!-- Header image -->
        </div>
        
        <!-- Content section (omitted for brevity) -->

    </div>

    <!-- Footer (omitted for brevity) -->

    <!-- JavaScript -->
    <script>
        // Define the initial message
        let message = "News: I update my site waaaaay too much. And I don't even have any social media to link!";

        // Function to wrap each letter of the message in <span> elements with individual animations
        function wrapLettersInSpans(message) {
            return message.split('').map(letter => `<span>${letter}</span>`).join('');
        }

        // Update the marquee content with the message and apply per-letter animation
        function updateMarquee() {
            const marqueeContent = document.getElementById('marquee');
            marqueeContent.innerHTML = wrapLettersInSpans(message);
        }

        // Call updateMarquee to set the initial message
        updateMarquee();
    </script>
</body>
</html>

This code adds individual <span> elements around each letter in the message and applies the sine wave animation to each letter separately. Let me know if you need further assistance!

You
Make it so that this css code gives an offset to each and every individual letter for the sine wave animation
ChatGPT

To apply an offset to each individual letter for the sine wave animation, you can modify the JavaScript code to generate spans for each letter with a unique delay for the animation. Here's how you can do it:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<title>Marquee Animation</title>
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="index.css">
</head>
<body>
<div class="marquee-container">
    <div class="marquee-background"></div>
    <div class="marquee-content" id="marquee"></div>
</div>

<script>
    // Define the initial message
    let message = "This is a scrolling message with individual letter animation";

    // Function to wrap each letter of the message in <span> elements with animation delay
    function wrapLettersInSpans(message) {
        return message.split('').map((letter, index) => {
            // Set a unique animation delay for each letter
            const delay = index * 0.1 + 's'; // Adjust the delay as needed
            return `<span style="animation-delay: ${delay};">${letter}</span>`;
        }).join('');
    }

    // Update the marquee content with the message
    function updateMarquee() {
        const marqueeContent = document.getElementById('marquee');
        marqueeContent.innerHTML = wrapLettersInSpans(message);
    }

    // Call updateMarquee to set the initial message
    updateMarquee();
</script>
</body>
</html>

With this code, each letter in the message will have a unique animation delay, creating an offset effect for the sine wave animation. Adjust the delay value (0.1s in this example) to control the speed of the animation.

You
the javascript now doesnt have spaces
ChatGPT

To include spaces in the JavaScript function while still applying individual animation delays to each letter, you can modify the function to handle spaces separately. Here's the updated JavaScript code:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<title>Marquee Animation</title>
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="index.css">
</head>
<body>
<div class="marquee-container">
    <div class="marquee-background"></div>
    <div class="marquee-content" id="marquee"></div>
</div>

<script>
    // Define the initial message
    let message = "This is a scrolling message with individual letter animation";

    // Function to wrap each letter of the message in <span> elements with animation delay
    function wrapLettersInSpans(message) {
        let wrappedMessage = '';
        let delay = 0;
        for (let i = 0; i < message.length; i++) {
            const char = message[i];
            // If the character is a space, add a non-breaking space with no animation
            if (char === ' ') {
                wrappedMessage += '&nbsp;';
            } else {
                // Set a unique animation delay for each letter
                const animationDelay = delay * 0.1 + 's'; // Adjust the delay as needed
                wrappedMessage += `<span style="animation-delay: ${animationDelay};">${char}</span>`;
                delay++;
            }
        }
        return wrappedMessage;
    }

    // Update the marquee content with the message
    function updateMarquee() {
        const marqueeContent = document.getElementById('marquee');
        marqueeContent.innerHTML = wrapLettersInSpans(message);
    }

    // Call updateMarquee to set the initial message
    updateMarquee();
</script>
</body>
</html>

In this updated code, spaces are preserved in the message, and individual animation delays are applied to each letter. Adjust the delay value (0.1s in this example) to control the speed of the animation.

ChatGPT

To ensure that the top of the text is not cut off by the margins, you can adjust the positioning of the .marquee-content within the .marquee-container. Here's the updated CSS code:

css
.marquee-container {
    position: relative;
    width: 100%;
    overflow: hidden;
    margin-top: 10px; /* Add top margin */
    margin-bottom: 10px; /* Add bottom margin */
}

.marquee-content {
    white-space: nowrap;
    position: absolute; /* Change position to absolute */
    top: 0; /* Align to the top of the container */
    left: 0;
    animation: marquee 20s linear infinite;
    font-family: dosfont2;
    color: black;
    overflow: hidden;
}

By setting the .marquee-content position to absolute and aligning it to the top of the container, you ensure that the text starts from the top of the container, avoiding the top margin cutting off the text. Adjust the margin values as needed for your layout.

    margin-bottom: 10px; /* Add bottom margin */
}

/* Marquee content styles */
.marquee-content {
    white-space: nowrap;
    position: relative; /* Position relative for pseudo-element */
    font-family: dosfont2;
    font-size:  x-large;
    color: black; /* Text color */
    overflow: hidden; /* Hide overflowing text */
}

/* Marquee background styles */
.marquee-background {
    position: absolute;
    top: 0;
    left: 0;
    width: 100%;
    height: 150%;
    background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.9);
}

/* Apply sine wave animation to each letter */
.marquee-content span {
    display: inline-block; /* Make each letter a block element */
    animation: sineWave 2s linear infinite; /* Apply sine wave animation */
}

/* Keyframes for sine wave animation */
@keyframes sineWave {
    0%, 100% { transform: translateY(0); }
    50% { transform: translateY(-10px); }
}

<body>
    <div id="bgcontainer"><div id="bg1"><div id="bg2"></div></div></div>
    <a href="/"><img class="title" src="/assets/TITLE.png"></a>
    <div class="container">
        <div class="header"> 
            <div class="header_img"></div> <!-- Header image -->
            <!-- Marquee container -->
            <div class="marquee-container">
                <div class="marquee-background"></div> <!-- Background div -->
                <div class="marquee-content" id="marquee"></div>
            </div>
        </div>
        <!-- Rest of your content -->
    </div>

    <!-- JavaScript -->
    <script>
        // Define the initial message
        let message = "This is a scrolling message with individual letter animation";

        // Function to wrap each letter of the message in <span> elements with animation delay
        function wrapLettersInSpans(message) {
            let wrappedMessage = '';
            let delay = 0;
            for (let i = 0; i < message.length; i++) {
                const char = message[i];
                // If the character is a space, add a non-breaking space with no animation
                if (char === ' ') {
                    wrappedMessage += '&nbsp;';
                } else {
                    // Set a unique animation delay for each letter
                    const animationDelay = delay * 0.1 + 's'; // Adjust the delay as needed
                    wrappedMessage += `<span style="animation-delay: ${animationDelay};">${char}</span>`;
                    delay++;
                }
            }
            return wrappedMessage;
        }

        // Update the marquee content with the message
        function updateMarquee() {
            const marqueeContent = document.getElementById('marquee');
            marqueeContent.innerHTML = wrapLettersInSpans(message);
        }

        // Call updateMarquee to set the initial message
        updateMarquee();
    </script>
</body>
</html>

In this updated code:

  • The .marquee-container is positioned absolutely and aligned to the bottom of the .header_img.
  • The marquee background and content remain positioned absolutely within the .marquee-container.
  • The JavaScript function to update the marquee content remains the same.

To make the message scroll horizontally, you can use CSS animations. Here's how you can modify the CSS:

css
/* Marquee content styles */
.marquee-content {
    white-space: nowrap;
    font-family: dosfont2;
    font-size: x-large;
    color: black;
    overflow: hidden;
    display: inline-block;
    animation: marqueeScroll 20s linear infinite; /* Add animation for scrolling */
}

/* Keyframes for marquee scrolling animation */
@keyframes marqueeScroll {
    0% { transform: translateX(100%); } /* Start offscreen from the right */
    100% { transform: translateX(-100%); } /* Scroll to offscreen on the left */
}

This will create a horizontal scrolling effect for the marquee content, making the message move from right to left continuously. Adjust the animation duration (20s) as needed to control the scrolling speed. Let me know if you need further assistance!
